Title: A logarithmic integral $\int^1_0 \frac{\log\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}{x\sqrt{1-x^2}}\,dx$
Content: How to prove the following $$\int^1_0 \frac{\log\left(\frac{1+x}{1-x}\right)}{x\sqrt{1-x^2}}\,dx=\frac{\pi^2}{2}$$ I thought of separating the two integrals and use the beta or hypergeometric functions but I thought these are not best ideas to approach the problem. Any other ideas ?
AcceptedAnswer:
After the change of variables $x=\tanh u$ (suggested by the square root) this integral reduces to
$$\mathcal{I}=\int_0^{\infty}\frac{2u\,du}{\sinh u}.$$
Expanding $\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sinh u}=2\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}e^{-(2k+1)u}$ and exchanging summation and integration, we find that
$$\mathcal{I}=4\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2k+1)^2}.$$
Standard manipulations express the last sum in terms of $\zeta(2)=\frac{\pi^2}{6}$:
$$\zeta(2)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(2k+1)^2}+\frac{\zeta(2)}{4}\quad \Longrightarrow \quad \displaystyle\mathcal{I}=3\zeta(2).$$
